summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to SEC officials, primarily dated July 2020, appealing a preliminary denial of his whistleblower award claim. Dilorio alleges the SEC is a corrupt organization that facilitates money laundering, fraud, and market manipulation through various shell companies and individuals, while obstructing his complaints. He specifically links several individuals and entities to Jeffrey Epstein, Trump associates, and Russian money.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of SEC corruption, money laundering, and fraud related to various shell companies and individuals. He is appealing a preliminary denial of his whistleblower award claim.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: Described as a prolific 'Bag Man' and the largest shareholder of SkyWay, who allegedly escaped SEC investigation. Later became CEO of Blink Charging (BLNK), which Dilorio claims is a money laundering shell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as a business partner of Andrew/Jonathan Farkas, a Trump fundraiser, linking the alleged fraud to Epstein.

persons.name: Andrew Farkas
persons.context: Identified as a Trump fundraiser and business partner of Jeffrey Epstein, adding a political element to the alleged BLNK fraud.

persons.name: Jonathan Farkas
persons.context: Referenced alongside Andrew Farkas as a Trump fundraiser and Epstein business partner involved in the BLNK fraud.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: Former New Mexico Governor linked to Jeffrey Epstein and his Zorro Ranch, described as 'the icing on the top' of the SEC-facilitated BLNK fraud.

persons.name: Keener
persons.context: Referred to as a 'Bag Man' known to the SEC, allegedly barred by FINRA but kept operational. Involved with JMJ and linked to money laundering shells like Blink Charging.

persons.name: Nordlicht
persons.context: Linked to Platinum Funds and involved in money laundering shells, with connections to Kushner and Trump lawyer Giuliani.

persons.name: Engel
persons.context: Drexel flunkie and board member of BLNK, linked to Milken.

persons.name: Scigliano
persons.context: Chairman of the Board, also a Director at Oleg Firer's Acies Corp, linked to Jaclin money laundering shells.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: Described as a prolific 'Bag Man' whose entity Acies Corp was incorporated at 14 Wall Street, linked to Rovt, Allied Wallet, and WireCard.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Linked to the Jaclin money laundering shell PRComplete/YESDtc through GRQ, mentioned as another 'Bag Man'.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Associated with Hanover/Magna and involved in multiple shell companies (CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead, FreeSeas, PRTH). Subject of an SEC complaint which Dilorio claims is based on his information.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: SEC official addressed in the emails, accused by Dilorio of not distributing his information within the SEC and failing to produce the record for his award determination.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: SEC official (likely from the Office of the Whistleblower) repeatedly addressed and accused of corruption and obstruction in handling Dilorio's claims.

persons.name: Jay
persons.context: SEC official mentioned alongside Janey and Hoecker, questioned about the NITE compliance department.

persons.name: Clayton
persons.context: SEC Chair accused of not disclosing his Sullivan & Cromwell/Fishman/NITE conflicts and called to step down immediately.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Chair Clayton, accused of playing a key role in keeping Knight Capital (NITE/VIRT) operational.

persons.name: Ajay Tandon
persons.context: Co-founder of SeeThroughEquity, LLC, named in an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump schemes related to Net Element (NETE).

persons.name: Amit Tandon
persons.context: Co-founder of SeeThroughEquity, LLC, named in an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump schemes related to Net Element (NETE).

connections.description: Described as business partners, linking financial fraud allegations to Epstein.
Both described as 'Bag Men' involved in money laundering shells like Blink Charging (BLNK) and SkyWay.
Linked to Jeffrey Epstein and his New Mexico Zorro Ranch.
Linked through money laundering shells and connections to Kushner and Trump lawyer Giuliani, within the broader context of Epstein-associated networks alleged by Dilorio.
Whistleblower corresponding with SEC official regarding his award claim and allegations of obstruction.
Scigliano was a Director at Firer's Acies Corp, linked to money laundering activities.
Both described as 'Bag Men' involved with Jaclin money laundering shells.
Colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell; Fishman accused of helping keep Knight Capital (NITE/VIRT) running.

events.title: SEC approves BLNK public offering
events.description: The SEC declared effective a public offering of securities for Blink Charging Co. (BLNK) despite Dilorio's submitted evidence alleging it is a money laundering shell.

events.title: BLNK press release drives stock surge
events.description: Blink Charging issued a press release about charging station grants, driving the stock up nearly 30% on high volume. Dilorio alleges this was a fraudulent pump-and-dump scheme as no required SEC 8-K filing was made.

events.title: Knight Capital trading glitch
events.description: A trading glitch caused Knight Capital Group's stock to collapse from over $10.30 to nearly $2.50. Dilorio implies this was orchestrated.

events.title: SEC charges UBS with AML violations
events.description: The SEC announced settled charges against UBS Financial Services Inc. for failing to report suspicious transactions, resulting in a $5 million penalty.

events.title: SEC complaint against SeeThroughEquity
events.description: The SEC brought a complaint against SeeThroughEquity, LLC and its founders for pump-and-dump schemes, which Dilorio links to promotions of Net Element (NETE).

events.title: FINRA bars Keener/JMJ
events.description: FINRA barred Justin Keener/JMJ as a 'Bad Actor' for anti-money laundering violations, but Dilorio alleges the SEC kept him operational.

events.title: SEC Jaclin shell factory complaint
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against Jaclin et al. for operating a 'shell factory,' which included New Image Concepts (later BLNK).

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher J. Dilorio, alleges the SEC is a criminal organization that actively facilitates money laundering, fraud, and market manipulation while obstructing his complaints and denying his award claims.

Multiple individuals, including Michael Farkas, Andrew/Jonathan Farkas, Keener, and Nordlicht, are accused of being 'Bag Men' operating money laundering shells like Blink Charging (BLNK), with links to Jeffrey Epstein, Trump fundraisers, and Russian money.
Dilorio claims the SEC approved a Blink Charging public offering in July 2020 and failed to act on a fraudulent press release, despite having his overwhelming evidence of the scheme.

The document connects the alleged financial fraud to prominent figures like ex-Governor Bill Richardson (linked to Epstein's Zorro Ranch) and SEC Chair Clayton (accused of undisclosed conflicts related to Knight Capital).

Dilorio asserts that his whistleblower information formed the basis for several SEC complaints (e.g., against Sason, SeeThroughEquity) but that the SEC simultaneously used his information while covering up larger criminal activities.
